Award.AwardTitle: Cluster Beam Deposition and Analysis of Metal Chalcogenide Nanoparticles in Organic Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Cluster beam deposition of metal chalcogenide nanoparticles into films is performed in combination with evaporative or ion-assisted deposition of an organic phase. These deposition methods improve control of nanoparticle surface chemistry and morphology for the development of high-efficiency, stable photovoltaic films. Nanoparticle surface chemistry and heterojunction bonding in films are probed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and laser desorption vacuum ultraviolet postionization mass spectrometry. Dynamic X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy is utilized to probe the photophysics of these films by examining their photoinduced charging in an element-specific fashion, without the need for metal overlayers for electrical contact.

Non-technical Description: This research project contributes to fundamental knowledge of the relationship of nanoparticle surface chemistry to film photovoltaic behavior and, ultimately, to production of high-efficiency solar cells using low-cost, abundant materials. One broader educational impact is the development of mentoring seminars for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. These seminars prepare participants for diverse careers in academia, industry, or government by discussing job placement, interviewing, proposals, job expectations, the balance of career with personal goals, and related issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cluster beam deposition of lead sulfide and copper sulfide nanoparticles was coupled with evaporation of organic oligomers and ion-assisted deposition to prepare thin films of interest to photovoltaics and other electronic device applications. A method of nanostructuring surfaces by low energy ion beam irradiation was also demonstrated. These all-gaseous processes permit direct control many aspects of nanostructures and nanoparticles including their stoichiometry, nanoscale dimensions, and interfaces with adjacent organic phases. Thus, these methods show great promise for optimizing nanostructures that are critical to the performance of many electronic devices and in nanoparticles with chemistry far beyond those explored here. Both methods are also compatible with lithography, are solvent free, and can prevent oxidative degradation. Three refereed papers resulted from this project.

This grant also helped develop femtosecond laser desorption postionization mass spectrometry for sub-micron lateral resolution mass spectrometric imaging of organic electronic devices as well as intact biological samples. It supported the publication of two refereed papers and a book chapter on laser desorption-based and related methods in MS imaging.

Finally, a series of career counseling workshops provided graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with guidance on developing careers in academia, industry, or government. These workshops discussed resume preparation, social media presence, networking skills, job placement guidance, interviewing strategies, the role of internships, and navigating the career-personal life balance. The following website was prepared which contains this and related material. chem.uic.edu/chemistry/resources-for-students

A method of nanostructuring surfaces by low energy ion beam irradiation was also demonstrated. These all-gaseous processes permit direct control many aspects of nanostructures and nanoparticles including their stoichiometry, nanoscale dimensions, and interfaces with adjacent organic phases. Thus, these methods show great promise for optimizing nanostructures that are critical to the performance of many electronic devices and in nanoparticles with chemistry far beyond those explored here. Both methods are also compatible with lithography, are solvent free, and can prevent oxidative degradation. Three refereed papers resulted from this project. This grant also helped develop femtosecond laser desorption postionization mass spectrometry for sub-micron lateral resolution mass spectrometric imaging of organic electronic devices as well as intact biological samples. It supported the publication of two refereed papers and a book chapter on laser desorption-based and related methods in MS imaging. Finally, a series of career counseling workshops provided graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with guidance on developing careers in academia, industry, or government. These workshops discussed resume preparation, social media presence, networking skills, job placement guidance, interviewing strategies, the role of internships, and navigating the career-personal life balance.
